awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Effects of Flow Regime Shifts, Anticendent  Hydrology, Nitrogen Pulses and Resource Quantity and Quality on Food Chain Length in Rivers
awd_abstract_narration:
The pattern of water flow in a river can affect the abundance of plants and animals and the food web that supports fisheries. Severe floods that scour the riverbed can potentially displace or kill plants and animals, however, little is known about how floods (or droughts) or the timing of these across years affects the complexity and diversity of food webs.  Some work suggests that river flow is a stronger determinant than the quantity of plant production on the flow of energy through the food web, but little is known about how the quality of plant food affects food chains and biodiversity. The study will provide fundamental information on how the timing of floods and droughts across years influences water quality (nitrate inputs to rivers), primary production, and the production of animals higher in the food web, such as fish.  The researchers will produce a synthesis of research in hydrology and ecology to improve the management of arid land rivers.  This work will reach across fundamental knowledge to education, from kindergarten to graduate levels.  The project will have numerous broader impacts including training of several undergraduates, graduate students, and a postdoc. Researchers will work with a non-profit group to integrate project findings into an existing citizen science program on river drying sponsored by The Nature Conservancy, and develop an environmental education program for grades K-5. Finally, the research team will establish an innovative open source, distributed graduate seminar on application of statistical methods in ecology.

Researchers will study streams spanning a gradient in the timing of rainfall to examine the role of changing hydrologic regimes in altering nitrogen supply, energy supply and food web structure in arid land streams.  This proposal will: 1) Quantify the effect of food quality, energy supply and energetic efficiencies on trophic structure, 2) Quantify the effects of time between floods on stimulation of plant production and trophic structure, and 3) Quantify the effect of changes in flow regime on trophic structure via direct mortality, shifts in plants at the base of the food web, and the structure of the food web.  Proposed research activities include characterization of the hydrologic regime, analysis of food webs across a hydroclimate gradient, and manipulation of nitrogen supply. Extreme event statistics and spectral analyses will characterize properties of flood intervals and flow regime shifts across 12 study sites spanning a gradient in timing of rainfall and hydrologic variation (monsoon vs. winter precipitation dominance) in Arizona. Derived hydrologic metrics will be used in combination with measures of ecosystem metabolism, N supply, secondary consumer energetic efficiencies, resource stoichiometry, and the proportion of autochthonous energy sources as predictor variables of food chain length and trophic structure to understand the mechanisms linking energetics and hydrology to food chain length. This comparative study includes 12 streams within the same biogeographic province that feature an algal-dominated food source and similar ecosystem size (1st-3rd order streams). Additionally researchers will conduct a nitrogen enrichment experiment in 6 streams to disentangle the indirect effects of water flow on nitrogen cycling versus the direct effects on plants and animals.

por.por_cntn:
Project objectives: The major goal of the project was to understand how temporal variation in streamflow influences food chain length and food web structure in streams. The length of food chains influences biodiversity and carbon storage in ecosystems. In freshwaters, longer food chains typically include larger fish, a source of protein in human diets. We studied 11 desert streams in Arizona (USA) that varied in streamflow due to differences in the seasonal distribution of precipitation. We monitored water chemistry, plant production, and organisms in the streams for three years. To test the role of nutrients, we experimentally fertilized six streams with nitrogen over two-week periods. 

Nutrients limit energy input and carbon storage in desert streams: As a part of the energy supply to ecosystems, photosynthesis by plants and algae supports food chains. Energy input from plants and algae growing in desert streams was nearly balanced with or less than energy lost due to respiration by organisms. Greater energy output compared to instream production indicates that organisms also relied on energy inputs from terrestrial ecosystems, such as leaf litter. Nitrogen, an essential nutrient for biota, enhanced activity of stream biota, including both photosynthesis and respiratory loss of energy. Nutrients were more available following storms, particularly when multiple storms occurred during rainier periods. These results suggest that productivity of streams will become more temporally variable as streamflows are characterized by longer or more intense droughts punctuated by large, but infrequent storms. 

Energy flow through food webs: Energy available to support food chains is diminished at each successive feeding level because it is lost to support the metabolic activity of organisms. This loss of energy could limit the number of links in a food chain, and the size or productivity of organisms. We estimated the efficiency of energy flow through food chains. We compared the energy input to streams from photosynthesis by algae with the biomass production of fish. The efficiency of energy flow through food chains declined with increased variability in streamflow. Energy flow was more efficient in colder streams with more stable flow regimes and greater light input. These results suggest decreased biodiversity and production of upper trophic levels under continued climate warming and increased droughts or more extreme precipitation events. 

Biodiversity and streamflow: Temporal variation in environmental conditions influence biodiversity and the particular species inhabiting an area. Punctuated, extreme environmental events (e.g., flash floods) cause mortality followed by recolonization of habitats. In addition, the long-term pattern, or regime, of environmental variation selects for adaptive traits. Fish communities of desert streams included more species when the long-term flow regime was relatively stable. However, species richness was less affected by large flood or drying events in streams with more temporally variable flow regimes. These patterns suggest that managed flow regimes should target stable flows to bolster species richness, but that inclusion of intermittent streams or those with temporally variable ambient flows in conservation plans could contribute to maintaining species richness at river basin or regional scales.

Scientific workforce training: This project provided significant training and career development to students at undergraduate, post-baccalaureate, graduate, and post-doctoral levels. The inter-disciplinary nature of the project, including hydrology, biodiversity, ecosystem production, food webs, and modeling expanded the expertise of trainees. The project supported 10 students in the Research Experience for Undergraduates program who independently collected and analyzed substantive datasets. An additional 30 undergraduate students gained at least a first exposure to ecological field work or laboratory analyses. The project supported six post-baccalaureate technicians who gained significant experience with project management and logistics, in addition to specialized technical skills. Two graduate students (one Ph.D., one M.S.) were supported by the project and completed theses that incorporated research from the project. The project supported two post-doctoral researchers, both of whom have established careers leading environmental research and monitoring groups.

Publicly available datasets:

-Water chemistry in 9-11 desert streams observed over 2-3 years 

-Gross primary production and ecosystem respiration of 9-11 desert streams at quarterly intervals for 2-3 years; and before, during, and after two weeks of fertilization with nitrate in six streams

-Amount and chemical composition of benthic organic matter accumulated over the dry, pre-monsoon season in 11 desert streams

-Accumulation of algal biomass (as chlorophyll a) in response to experimental nitrogen and phosphorus addition in 11 desert streams

-Quarterly observations of fish species diversity in nine desert streams
